ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
What is your overall rating of the primary instructor?
The primary instructor's sensitivity to students and ability to provide students with adequate feedback was:

narratives.question_text: Indicate the total number of hours per week (outside the classroom) you spent on this course:
comments: 1 hour roughly bi-weekly
1 hour when a lunch was scheduled that week.
0. You go to the seminar, grab free food, and listen to a guest speaker talk about their research -- interesting stuff!
less than 1 hour
60 minutes
2 hours

narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: The seminars are interesting. I thought there were more memorable ones last semester, but they were OK this time around too. It's not really an issue of the speakers - most of the speakers that come in are clearly experts in their field and are able to talk about some interesting things they do. But I yearn to more stimulated by these talks. I think there should be a greater diversity of issues brought to the table, and possibly bring in some people who aren't doing research, but rather who are out in the field affecting change. They're both critical, but I think there's a lacking of the latter.
It's fine. Nothing gained, nothing lost. I appreciate that it's only a few talks.
A semester of interesting and engaging speakers!

Its strengths are that we learned about a range of research going on in the social and behavioral sciences field. The weakness was that sometimes the speaker's work was not relevant or pertinent to students interests (obviously this depends on the student). I think it also could be helpful to distribute some readings/publications from the person speaking that day so that students could get a sense of their work.

I liked it! The guest speakers were good and there was FREE FOOD! I would have liked to have seen more diverse groups of speakers, though. All of the speakers this semester presented only on their research. I would have loved to have seen guest speakers who are doing practice-based work and not solely research.

Strength - it provides a variety of research professors in social and behavioral sciences and epidemiology Weakness - it does not include many professionals outside of academia Ways to improve - bring public health practitioners who are not in academia
I really enjoyed the seminar series, but I wish we had a space to discuss the presentations we saw more. Also, sometimes there wasn't enough vegetarian food.

The speakers were a great mix of public health people with different research interests, which I really appreciated. I think the seminar could be improved by inviting a greater variety of speakers, especially by including those who might not be working in academia, as many SBS students are not interested in going into research.
Really interesting speakers and yummy lunch! Would like to have public health professionals as well as academics for speakers.

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Danya Keene  Danya's a great person :) Not really sure why this question is here for seminar - any way to customize this survey?
Instructor: Danya Keene  Danya didn't teach this; each seminar was a visitor to Yale giving a talk about their work. However, Danya is an amazing teacher in her actual class :)
Instructor: Danya Keene  She seemed great! Didn't have very much interaction with her.
Instructor: Danya Keene  Danya is awesome!
Instructor: Danya Keene  N/A - It is a seminar series
Instructor: Danya Keene  Dr. Keene is a great professor who is very responsive to students.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Free food, required to go, sometimes interesting lectures, so yes I recommend this course!
You attend people's talks a few times per semester and you get credit. The MPH students don't really speak, we just sit and listen for an hour.
A semester of interesting and engaging speakers!
This is a necessary requirement for the SBS track. Some speakers are fascinating and some are not, but you'll learn new ideas / research methods.
Love these seminars.
It is beneficial because it exposes us to SBS topics outside of our regular courses.
This seminar has expanded my knowledge of what kinds of things are possible to do in public health, and I've gotten to interact with really interesting professors. I recommend it!
Interesting seminar series that lets you hear about a lot of current research
